titles.title: Meshorerim [choir singers] at the house of Rabbi Baruch Rabinowitz, Mukacevo

makers.displaydate: 1897–1990; born St. Petersburg, Russia; died New York, NY; active Berlin, Germany, and New York City, NY
makers.displaymaker: Roman Vishniac, 1897–1990; born St. Petersburg, Russia; died New York, NY; active Berlin, Germany, and New York City, NY

texts.textentryhtml: International Center of Photography, purchased by the Princeton University Art Museum, December 2017.

In his description of In the market, Kazimierz, Krakow, Vishniac identifies the woman as Mrs. Shmulevich, a widow with four children. Though her business had been ruined by anti-Semitic boycotts, she continued to travel to the open-air market out of habit. Vishniac captured this moment between Shmulevich and a tax collector, who demanded payment lest he confiscate her merchandise. Shmulevich responded, "I don’t have anything." The collector replied, "Then I’ll take your food." She answered, "I don’t have any bread, and the sugar tin is empty. Only salt is left, to eat it alone is too bitter." In contrast to this story of desolation, Vishniac’s image of choir singers emphasizes the ways in which Jewish communities maintained traditions in the face of discrimination and violence.

displaymaker: Roman Vishniac, 1897–1990; born St. Petersburg, Russia; died New York, NY; active Berlin, Germany, and New York City, NY
caption: Roman Vishniac (1897–1990; born St. Petersburg, Russia; died New York, NY; active Berlin, Germany, and New York City, NY), Meshorerim [choir singers] at the house of Rabbi Baruch Rabinowitz, Mukacevo, ca. 1937–38, printed after 1950. Gelatin silver print; 36.4 × 48.3 cm (image), 40.5 × 50.5 cm (sheet). Museum purchase, Hugh Leander Adams, Mary Trumbull Adams and Hugh Trumbull Adams Princeton Art Fund (2017-232)
